data.text: Contents
Introduction

Mid  and  South  Essex  NHS  Foundation  Trust  (‘the  Trust')  has responsibility  to ensure that licences are obtained to permit the playing aloud of copyrighted music in  public  and  staff  areas  within  Trust  premises  other  than  inpatient  or  clinical treatment areas in accordance with the Copyright, Designs and Patents Act 1988 (‘the Act').

The Act 1988 states that if you use copyrighted recorded music in public you must first obtain the permission of every writer or composer of the music you intend to play, therefore music licences are required. The music licence(s) gives you the legal permission  to  play  any  copyrighted  music  controlled  by  the  regulatory  body. Licences are required regardless of the ownership of any type of licence i.e. a TV licence. Without such licences the Trust is in breach of the copyright laws and this could lead to legal action against the Trust by one of the licencing bodies i.e. Performing Rights Society (PRS) & or Phonographic Performance Ltd (PPL). PRS collects and distributes royalty money on behalf of songwriters and composers and the PPL collects money for use of recorded music on behalf of record companies and performers under separate licences and their own terms and conditions.
Scope
The purpose of this document is to:
Manage the playing of recorded copyrighted music within the Trust premises;

To ensure that the Trust remain legally compliant with its obligations in relation to this matter at all times by providing guidance to all Trust staff on the legal requirements and licencing requirement criteria;
Defining responsibilities for obtaining the licence(s) and payment thereof;
Establish a consistent Trust wide process for the management and monitoring of licencing within each Directorate to ensure compliance with this legislation.

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust
Individual responsibilities (i.e. Chief Executive)

The Chief Estates and Facilities officer ensures there is an effective policy on the playing of recorded copyrighted music within any of the premises managed by the Trust and that the Trust meets its legal obligations.

Directorate Senior Managers are responsible for ensuring all staff are aware of and adhere to this policy and associated local procedures and for the authorisation, acquisition, payment as well as monitoring of compliance to licence(s) within their areas.
Nominated Estates and Facilities Manager reviews and updates policy and arranges coordination of annual licence renewal on behalf of Trust.

All staff are responsible for having an awareness of the policy access and ensuring that recorded copyrighted music is not played aloud in non-treatment areas within the Trust unless the necessary licence has been obtained.
Qualifying criteria and exemptions
The following modes of playing music fall under the licencing requirement:
Radios/CD Players;
Personal CD Players*;
IPods*;
Music videos played on TVs;
Hold music on the telephone system;
Live performances e.g. in the Tower block lobby area, Atrium space.
* Exempt provided headphones are personally provided (not by Trust) and music is only audible to individual wearing the headphones.
Public areas that DO qualify under the licensing requirements include:
Offices;
Dining Facilities (including Break and Rest rooms);
Lobbies, Reception and waiting areas;
Shop floors;
Corridors.
Direct patient care areas remain exempt from licencing requirement as outline by PRS and PPL organisations including:
Wards (inpatient /day-stay);
Outpatient clinical treatment areas;
Theatres;
Physiotherapy and Rehabilitation departments, when music is an integral Part of Treatment e.g. music therapy.
Appendix 1 details PPL's discretionary policy for NHS premises.
Tariffs for public use of sound recordings
The tariffs that may be applicable to the Trust are as follows; PPL licences:
Background Music Tariff- Factories and Offices PPLPP212;
Background Music Tariff- Waiting Rooms/Reception areas PPLPP085;
Background Music Tariff- Shops and Stores PPLPP211;
Background Music Tariff- Public Houses/Bars/Restaurants & Cafes/Hotels PPLPP210.

Concessionary discounts of 50% may be available for office areas with an audible area of 100m2 or less, shops and stores with an audible area of 50m2 or less, and restaurants & cafés with audible area of 50m2 or less, provided only “traditional” radio  broadcasts  are  used  (i.e.  BBC  national  and  local  radio  stations  and independent local radio stations). Waiting areas do not have applicable discounts.
However surcharges of 50% maybe chargeable per area if recorded music has been played without due licensing.
Full details in accordance with current tariffs are published on the PPL PRS website; https://pplprs.co.uk/business/other/
Process for obtaining licences
A Trust Licence(s) will be obtained by the Estates and Facilities Directorate on behalf of areas approved for licensing by the Directorate lead(s) and Trust Corporate Management team.

Licensing and renewal will be on an annual basis for the approved areas on receipt of a completed authorised proforma and budget code (on a recurrent basis) from the Directorate's nominated responsible person(s).
Licences for charitable or special events
In cases where a charitable or special event(s) is organised and music is required; a temporary music licence can be obtained from the respective licensing organisations.
This temporary licence will cover the playing of copyrighted music, although certain stipulations will be placed upon the Trust by the licensing organisations.
Temporary licencing will be obtained by the event organiser.

Licensing and renewal will be on an annual basis for the approved areas on receipt of a completed authorised proforma and budget code (on a recurrent basis) from the Directorate's nominated responsible person(s).
Non Trust staff

Any non-Trust personnel working on Trust premises are expected to abide by the Trust Policy at all times. External organisations and contractors working on site must ensure that they have the appropriate licences in place to play copyrighted music. If the required licences are not in place, the Trust should prohibit any external organisations or contractors from playing copyrighted music aloud while working on the Trust premises.

Any  actions/fines  imposed  by  a  regulatory  body  (PRS  or  PPL)  in  respect  of copyright infringement by an external organisation or contractor working for the Trust is solely the responsibility of the former. The Trust accepts no responsibility or liability for their actions.
However, the Trust must ensure that non-Trust personnel are made aware of such regulations e.g. in their contractual conditions or service level agreements.
Training requirements
No specific training requirements.

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the EFM Governance board, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local policy guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the Business Development Unit of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.

NHS discretionary policy to reflect the not-for-profit nature of solely NHS premises and links to tariffs:

table_items.text: If recorded music is used by private patients or a mix of Private and NHS patients in respect of any beds/ wards this use will be licensable, but only for these beds/wards. View Supply of recorded music to Hotel Bedrooms, PPLPP213 tariff on the PPLPRS website.
Beds/wards that are utilised solely by NHS only patients would be exempt from the requirement under PPL's own internal NHS policy.

Where recorded music is used during the treatment of private patients or where the music use does not form an integral part of the treatment of a NHS patient, this use is licensable. For example, if a physiotherapist plays recorded music while treating patients the use of recorded music is not integral to the treatment then such usage will be licensable. This use would be licensable under the Background Music Tariff- Factories & Offices, PPLPP212.

As a matter of policy PPL does not charge for the use of recorded music when played as an integral part of treatment/rehabilitation in NHS hospitals. For example, if recorded music is used as part of music therapy for Alzheimer's patients PPL would not charge for such usage.

Where recorded music is used in areas open to the general public such as restaurants, cafes, shops (including charity shops) all uses are licensable. The applicable PPL tariffs will be applied. View Background Music Tariff - Shops & Stores, PPLPP211, Background Music Tariff - Public Houses/Bars/Restaurants and Cafes/Hotels, PPLPP210 on the PPLPRS website.
Staff Only Areas (Offices, Labs, Kitchens, Staff gyms etc.)

Where recorded music is used in staff only areas such as offices, staff restaurants/cafes, or staff gyms, all usage is licensable and should be licenced under the Background Music Tariff - Factories & Offices, PPLPP212.
Any use of music in waiting/reception areas is licensable under PPL's Background Music Tariff - Waiting Rooms/Reception Areas, PPLPP085
